Quoth Peter Kleczka: [...]
> As I understand it, if you're not explicitly 
> testing for a specific exception or lack of 
> a thrown exception, that you don't need the 
> try/catch.

Testing that a specific exception is thrown does, as you say,
require try/catch:
	public void testFoo() {
		try {
			exceptionShouldBeThrownHere();
			fail( "no exception was thrown!" );
		} catch (FooException e) {}
	}

Testing that *no* exception is thrown doesn't, since uncaught
exceptions are considered test failures:
	public void testBar() throws FooException {
		noExceptionShouldBeThrownHere();
	}
(Well, errors actually, not failures, but the difference hardly
matters.)

Catching an exception just to print its stack trace (as in the
code you report seeing) is silly.  Let the framework take care of
the reporting.
